tossups.question: This phrase was turned into a question on the cover of a 1966 Time magazine edition that featured the views of Thomas Altizer. In the prologue of one work, the protagonist states this phrase after registering his surprise that an “old saint in the forest” has not received its meaning. A passage best known for using this phase asks “How could we drink up the sea? Who gave us the sponge to wipe away the entire horizon?” and “Who will wipe this (*) blood off us?” in regards to the event that it describes. This phrase was first used by its best-known proponent in the “Parable of the Madman” found in his book The Gay Science. For 10 points, give this three-word phrase used several times by Friedrich Nietzsche (“NEE-chuh”), according to which a divinity is deceased.
tossups.answer: “God is dead” [or “Gott ist tot”; accept “Is God dead?”] <WA, Phil/Thought>
tossups.answer_formatted: “God is dead” [or “Gott ist tot”; accept “Is God dead?”]

tossups.question: At a conference held in this province, Winston Churchill and Franklin Roosevelt agreed to never use nuclear technology against each other. In this province, the photograph “Face to Face” was taken during a standoff over the construction of a golf course on indigenous land called the Oka Crisis. The 72 Resolutions were passed during an 1864 conference held in this province, where conservative dominance was ended by the (*) “Quiet Revolution.” The Meech Lake Accords were intended to fix unrest in this province. The War Measures Act was invoked during the October Crisis caused by this province’s Front for Liberation, which was opposed by Pierre Trudeau. For 10 points, name this separatist Canadian province whose largest city is Montreal.
tossups.answer: Quebec <ML, Commonwealth/Misc>
tossups.answer_formatted: Quebec <ML, Commonwealth/Misc>

tossups.question: “Twisting” these objects allows processes to be predicted using crossing symmetry. Elements of the S-matrix can be calculated perturbatively by summing an infinite number of these objects in a Dyson series. Corrections to classical processes are treated with “one-loop” examples of these objects. The relative contribution of one of these objects to an interaction is inversely related to the number of primitive vertices it has. Some “virtual” entities are represented by (*) squiggly lines that begin and end within these objects. Their axes (“AX-eez”) represent space and time, with antiparticles being shown on them as moving backward in time. For 10 points, name these diagrams that depict quantum mechanical processes, which are named for an American physicist.
tossups.answer: Feynman diagrams <WA, Physics>
tossups.answer_formatted: Feynman diagrams <WA, Physics>

tossups.question: In a poem in this form, the speaker laments, “The waste remains, the waste remains and kills.” This form was used for the poem “Missing Dates” by William Empson, who repopularized it in the 1930s, and was established by a poem about a lost turtledove by Jean Passerat. The speaker of a poem in this form recalls “two rivers, a continent” and says “I miss them, but it wasn’t a disaster.” Another poem in this form describes (*) “wise men at their end” who “know dark is right.” Refrains used in poems of this form include “The art of losing isn’t hard to master,” found in Elizabeth Bishop’s “One Art,” and “rage, rage against the dying of the light.” For 10 points, five tercets and a concluding quatrain comprise what nineteen-line poetic form, exemplified by Dylan Thomas’s “Do not go gentle into that good night?”
tossups.answer: villanelle <NC, Poetry>
tossups.answer_formatted: villanelle <NC, Poetry>

tossups.question: Beethoven’s Triple Concerto is most often played by a glamorous all-female trio from Juilliard (“JOO-lee-ard”) named for this word. The trio section of a solo piano piece titled for this adjective begins with 6 rolled E major chords before a fast left-hand ostinato of E, D-sharp, C-sharp, and B octaves. That Opus 53 solo piece titled for this adjective begins with a loud E-flat octave in both hands, then chromatic ascending first-inversion triads. This adjective sometimes names a composer’s middle period spanning the decade after (*) 1803. George Sand gave this nickname to a Polonaise in A-flat major after the 1848 Revolution in France. Before a funeral march in C minor, two E-flat major tutti chords open a symphony titled for this adjective originally dedicated to Napoleon. For 10 points, what adjective names a Chopin polonaise and Beethoven’s triumphant Third Symphony?
tossups.answer: heroic [accept Eroica Symphony; accept Heroic Polonaise or Polonaise héroïque; accept Eroica Trio; accept heroic period or heroic phase or heroic style; prompt on polonaise or Polish by asking “what’s the other title word?”] <RK, Classical/Opera>
tossups.answer_formatted: heroic [accept Eroica Symphony; accept Heroic Polonaise or Polonaise héroïque; accept Eroica Trio; accept heroic period or heroic phase or heroic style; prompt on polonaise or Polish by asking “what’s the other title word?”]
promptable: Polish by asking “what’s the other title word?”

tossups.question: The CSRW in Boulder, Colorado, maintains a truck fleet, called this effect “on wheels,” which was deployed in Argentina for the RELAMPAGO project. Measurements based on this effect taken at different elevation slices are aggregated into a “volume coverage pattern” by the WSR-88D system, better known as NEXRAD (“nex-rad”). “Hook echoes” appear because the change in (*) phase due to this effect is greater when studying rapidly rotating mesocyclones. To study the movement of precipitation, meteorologists use pulse timing to detect position and use this effect to detect velocity. This effect is also exploited in “speed guns” used by police. A namesake form of weather radar takes advantage of, for 10 points, what effect that causes redshift, in which moving wave sources appear to have different frequencies?
tossups.answer: Doppler effect [accept Doppler on Wheels or Doppler shift or Doppler radar] <WA, Earth Science>
tossups.answer_formatted: Doppler effect [accept Doppler on Wheels or Doppler shift or Doppler radar]

tossups.question: The orders of bread, garments, hides, and construction are categories of restrictions during this observance that, like the number of lashes inflicted on violators, number “forty minus one” in total. This observance is mentioned in the first verses of the songs Yism’chu (“YISS-meh-khoo”), V’shamru (“veh-SHOM-roo”), and L’cha dodi (“leh-KHA doh-DEE”). During this observance, synagogues are often assisted by a gentile or goy. To be consistent with this observance, some “kosher” phones have continuously (*) running electricity and some elevators stop at every floor. This is the only observance mentioned in the Ten Commandments, which says to “remember” it. This observance starts with the woman of the house lighting candles, after which the kiddush is recited. Working is prohibited on, for 10 points, what holy Jewish day of rest that begins at sundown every Friday?
tossups.answer: Sabbath [or Shabbat; or Shabbos; accept Shabbos goy or Shabbat elevator or Sabbath mode] <WA, Religion>
tossups.answer_formatted: Sabbath [or Shabbat; or Shabbos; accept Shabbos goy or Shabbat elevator or Sabbath mode]

tossups.question: Binding partners of this structure often interact through anchor residues. Mutations in RFX5 lead to the inability to process this structure in a syndrome in which certain cells are described as “bare.” An asterisk is used to separate the name of a portion of this structure from a specific allele. The immunoproteasome is used to load peptides into this structure, where they can be recognized by the (*) TCR. Polymorphisms in this structure are associated with various autoimmune conditions. Antigen-presenting cells express class II of this structure, while all cells use class I to present viral peptides. For 10 points, name this highly complex glycoprotein that must be matched in organ transplants, and that is used by the immune system to distinguish self from non-self.
tossups.answer: major histocompatibility complex [or MHC; accept MHC class I, MHC class II, or MHC class III; prompt on Human Leukocyte Antigen or HLA or H-2] <EM, Biology: Immuno>
tossups.answer_formatted: major histocompatibility complex [or MHC; accept MHC class I, MHC class II, or MHC class III; prompt on Human Leukocyte Antigen or HLA or H-2]
acceptable: MHC class I, MHC class II,

tossups.question: A novel by this author depicts the demise of the Baudu (“bo-DYOO”) family’s shop amidst the rise of a department store inspired by contemporary Rive Gauche (“reev gohsh”) life called the Ladies’ Paradise. The protagonist of another of this author’s novels witnesses an “age-old resignation… swept aside” as the horse Bataille (“bah-TIE”) attempts to survive a flood. Many of this author’s novels were serialized by the periodical Gil Blas (“zheel blah”), including one whose protagonist falls in love with the (*) tram-cart pusher Catherine Maheu (“kaht-REEN mah-OO”) and kills her lover Chaval (“shuh-VAHL”) after a failed strike by coal miners. This author’s 20-novel series Les Rougons-Macquart (“lay roo-GON-muh-CAR”) contains a novel about Étienne Lantier (“ate-YEN lont-YAY”) titled Germinal (“zhair-mee-NALL”). For 10 points, name this author who attacked the anti-Semitism faced by Alfred Dreyfus (“dray-FOOSE”) in his open letter J’Accuse…! (“zha-KYOOZ”)
tossups.answer: Émile Zola <CQ, Long Fiction>
tossups.answer_formatted: Émile Zola <CQ, Long Fiction>

tossups.question: William B. Lowry led a Confederate company that was primarily recruited from this institution, called the University Greys, which suffered a 100-percent casualty rate at Pickett’s Charge. This university’s chancellor Alfred Hume prevented Governor Theodore G. Bilbo from moving it to the state capital. The deaths of French journalist Paul Guihard (“ghee-ARR”) and repairman Ray Gunter in a riot at this university are explored in an ESPN documentary titled for its Ghosts. Governor (*) Ross Barnett became a registrar at this university and physically blocked an office to prevent the registration of an Air Force veteran, whereupon John F. Kennedy threatened to use the Army to enforce its desegregation. Federal marshals ensured that James Meredith was able to enroll in, for 10 points, what flagship Southern state university located in Oxford?
tossups.answer: University of Mississippi [or Ole Miss; or UMiss; accept Ghosts of Ole Miss; do not accept or prompt on “Mizzou”] <AA, US History>
tossups.answer_formatted: University of Mississippi [or Ole Miss; or UMiss; accept Ghosts of Ole Miss; do not accept or prompt on "“Mizzou”"]

tossups.question: Description acceptable. This specific vehicle titles a pseudonymous 2016 essay that likens a hypothetical Hillary Clinton presidency to “Russian Roulette with a semi-auto.” Michael Anton used the name “Publius Decius Mus” to write that essay titled for this vehicle, which names a crescent-shaped memorial with a white marble “Wall of Names” that includes Debbie Welsh and Lauren Grandcolas. The phrase “let’s roll” was recorded by this vehicle’s (*) black box, which was found along with it in Shanksville. Todd Beamer attacked a man who piloted this vehicle for 25 minutes, Ziad Jarrah, helping thwart a plan created by Khalid Sheikh Mohammed that targeted the US Capitol. For 10 points, name or describe this vehicle, on which a 2001 passenger revolt prevented hijackers from hitting anything except a field in Pennsylvania.
tossups.answer: United Airlines Flight 93 [or UAL 93; accept answers indicating the aircraft that crash-landed in Shanksville, Pennsylvania on 9/11, or the aircraft hijacked on 9/11 that never hit any buildings; prompt on plane or airplane or aircraft, or 9/11 plane, etc.] <WA, Other Academic>
tossups.answer_formatted: United Airlines Flight 93 [or UAL 93; accept answers indicating the aircraft that crash-landed in Shanksville, Pennsylvania on 9/11,accept the aircraft hijacked on 9/11 that never hit any buildings; prompt on plane or airplane or aircraft, or 9/11 plane, etc.]
acceptable: answers indicating the aircraft that crash-landed in Shanksville, Pennsylvania on 9/11,
aircraft hijacked on 9/11 that never hit any buildings

tossups.question: A protest movement in the former lands of this kingdom began when a group of intellectuals left a declaration of independence with their check at a restaurant. Academics in this kingdom were targeted by the “Short Hair Act,” part of a set of reforms passed after its empress was assassinated. The March 1st Movement sought to restore the independence of this kingdom, which was made a protectorate in the aftermath of the Treaty of (*) Portsmouth and annexed five years later. Before her death, Empress Myeongseong (“m’yung-sung”) reformed the yangban caste system in this kingdom, which lost its traditional Chinese protection after the 1894 Sino-Japanese War. For 10 points, name this kingdom whose Joseon (“choh-sun”) dynasty was ended when it was conquered by Japan.
tossups.answer: Korea [accept Choson or Joseon until “Joseon” is read; accept Hanguk] <ML, World History>
tossups.answer_formatted: Korea [accept Choson or Joseon until “Joseon” is read; accept Hanguk]

tossups.question: Arnold Goldstein developed a cognitive behavioral technique that seeks to alter this behavior amongst adolescents, called “replacement training.” A “general” model of this behavior that analyzes how it is influenced by the media was proposed by Anderson and Bushman. A 1939 paper by Dollard, Doob, Miller, Mower, and Sears proposed that this behavior is “displaced” onto new targets when it arises from (*) frustration. In a 1961 experiment, video recordings of models that differed in this behavior were shown to two different groups of children at the Stanford University nursery; one of the models that exhibited [emphasize] more of this behavior yelled phrases such as “Sockaroo!” For 10 points, name this behavior that children socially learned in a study by Albert Bandura, leading them to attack a Bobo doll.
tossups.answer: aggression [or aggressiveness; accept aggression replacement training or aggression-frustration hypothesis; prompt on violence or attacking; do not accept or prompt on “bullying”] <RK, Social Science: Psych>
tossups.answer_formatted: aggression [or aggressiveness; accept aggression replacement training or aggression-frustration hypothesis; prompt on violence or attacking; do not accept or prompt on "“bullying”"]

tossups.question: A bunch of blue diagonal lines pierce passengers in one entry in a triptych from this art movement set at a train station. A Precisionist artist from this movement who immigrated to the US created several paintings that show gray, metallic cityscapes through the arches of the Brooklyn Bridge. An artist from this movement painted the States of Mind triptych and acted on his desire to separate from “analytical discontinuity” by creating a sculpture that uses two separate blocks as (*) pedestals for a figure modeled on the Nike of Samothrace. The feet of a dachshund are blurred in painting from this movement titled Dynamism of a Dog on a Leash by Giacomo Balla. The sculpture Unique Forms of Continuity in Space is from, for 10 points, what mostly Italian art movement that celebrated war and technology?
tossups.answer: Futurism [or Futurismo] (The first clue refers to the painting Those Who Go.) <AR, Painting/Sculpture>
tossups.answer_formatted: Futurism [or Futurismo]
tossups.metadata: The first clue refers to the painting Those Who Go.

tossups.question: A wealthy character in this play promises to donate to charity if a man succeeds in playing “monkey tricks” on his brother. In this play, a man repeatedly rings a bell to silence a crowd during a speech lambasting the rule of the “majority.” This play ends as its protagonist claims that the “strongest man” is one who “stands alone.” A schoolteacher in this play refuses to translate a book from English for a newspaper edited by (*) Hovstad called The People’s Messenger. In its final act, Captain Horster loses his job before his planned voyage to America. In this play, the mayor Peter refuses to pay for the re-laying of pipes that lead from Morten Kiil’s tannery to the polluted town baths. For 10 points, name this Henrik Ibsen play in which the citizens vote to give Dr. Thomas Stockmann the title moniker.
tossups.answer: An Enemy of the People [or En Folkefiende] <NC, Drama>
tossups.answer_formatted: An Enemy of the People [or En Folkefiende]

tossups.question: Krishna wrestles one of these non-primate animals for 28 days to recover the Syamantaka gem. Athenian girls play-acted as these animals during rituals at the cult site of Brauron. The Hindu king of these animals is named Jambavan. Another of them named Ungnyeo (“oong-nyuh”) was sealed into a cave with a tiger, and then transformed into a woman who gave birth to Dangun (“DAHN-goon”), who founded a nation. Zeus took the guise of (*) Artemis to rape a nymph who was turned into one of these animals by Hera after being expelled from Artemis’s entourage. The Korean creation of humanity features a female example of these animals. One of these animals was turned into a constellation when her son Arcas almost shot her dead. For 10 points, what animal did Callisto become before being set in the sky as Ursa Major?
tossups.answer: bears [accept specific varieties such as sloth bears or grizzly bears] <AR, Myths/Legends>
tossups.answer_formatted: bears [accept specific varieties such as sloth bears or grizzly bears]
acceptable: specific varieties such as sloth bears

tossups.question: This many reactants combine to form an amide in the Ugi reaction. A ring with this many total phosphorus and sulfur atoms is found at the center of Lawesson’s reagent. Cyclizing acrolein (“uh-CRO-lee-in”) creates a ring with this many members called oxetane. This is the smallest number of d electrons for which a complex can exist in either high or low spin states. This is the number of atoms in a face-centered cubic unit cell. A ring of this size distinguishes a class of antibiotics that includes (*) penicillin, which are known as beta-lactams. White phosphorus consists of molecules containing this many phosphorus atoms. When a central atom is bonded to this many ligands, it can take on seesaw or tetrahedral geometry. For 10 points, what is the atomic number of beryllium?
tossups.answer: four [or 4] <RN, Chemistry>

tossups.question: A film from this country intercuts shots of fish with beads of water while two characters hide in trees after they rob a love motel whose residents had been murdered by a 12-year-old. An “aesthetics of hunger” characterizes this country’s film Black God, White Devil. A man in a skeleton costume chases a Greek hero and his lover through the streets of this country in Marcel Camus’s (“ka-MOO’s”) 1959 film Black Orpheus, which was criticized by its socially conscious (*) “New Cinema” movement. Another film from here begins and ends with a sequence that uses fast cuts to depict boys chasing a chicken. That film from here focuses on Rocket, who becomes a photographer while Li’l Zé becomes a gang leader. The violent movie City of God is set in, for 10 points, what country whose films often feature its bossa nova music and favelas?
tossups.answer: Brazil [or Federative Republic of Brazil] <RK, Other Arts: Film>
tossups.answer_formatted: Brazil [or Federative Republic of Brazil]

tossups.question: This author called facts “brute beasts” and claimed that all “practical wisdom” extends the formula “2 + 2 = 4” in an essay subtitled “Every Man His Own Boswell.” This author’s time as a physician led him to publish some “medicated novels” and Medical Essays, as well as coin the term “anesthesia.” This author provided the name for The Atlantic Monthly magazine as well as a “caste” of New England elites known as the (*) “Boston Brahmins,” who he mocked in his “Breakfast-Table” series. This author declared “Ay, tear (“tair”) her tattered ensign down!” in a poem that saved the USS Constitution from being decommissioned. Another of his poems describes a “ship of pearl” that sings “Build thee more stately mansions.” For 10 points, name this Fireside poet of “Old Ironsides” and “The Chambered Nautilus.”
tossups.answer: Oliver Wendell Holmes Sr. [do not accept or prompt on “Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr.”] <ML, Misc Lit>
tossups.answer_formatted: Oliver Wendell Holmes Sr. [do not accept or prompt on "“Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr.”"]

tossups.question: This ruler once cut open a gardener to find a precious missing cucumber he had grown. Another ruler nailed the hats of this ruler’s emissaries to their heads after they refused to remove them. This ruler codified the practice of successful princes murdering their brothers upon taking the throne with his Law of Fratricide. He proclaimed that Christianity “has lost its sword and shield” and was able to subdue Albania after the death of his long-time foe (*) Skanderbeg. Vlad the Impaler led the Night Attack to assassinate this son of Murad II. He used giant cannons created by the Hungarian engineer Orban to take a city ruled by the Palaeologus (“pay-lee-AW-luh-gus”) dynasty, thus ending the Roman Empire. For 10 points, name this Ottoman sultan who gained his best-known epithet by seizing Constantinople.
tossups.answer: Mehmed II [or Mehmed the Conqueror or Mehmed Fatih; prompt on Mehmed] <NC, European History>  If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions.   Bonuses
tossups.answer_formatted: Mehmed II [or Mehmed the Conqueror or Mehmed Fatih; prompt on Mehmed]

bonuses.leadin: The stability of systems featuring these two types of populations is determined by a community matrix. For 10 points each:
answers: predators AND prey [accept predator–prey systems]
differential equations [or diffy Qs; accept linear differential equations, nonlinear differential equations, ordinary differential equations, ODEs, partial differential equations, or PDEs]
bifurcations [accept Hopf bifurcations] <WA, Applied Math/Misc>
parts: Identify these two types of populations that are modeled by the Lotka–Volterra equations, which describe how their sizes influence one another.
The Lotka–Volterra equations are first-order examples of this sort of equation, as they relate functions to their derivatives.

When a food source suddenly increases, predator–prey populations tend toward limit cycles after undergoing one of these phenomena named for Hopf. In general, these phenomena occur in chaotic systems when a small change to the parameters of a system results in a sudden change in behavior.
answers_formatted: differential equations [or diffy Qs; accept linear differential equations, nonlinear differential equations, ordinary differential equations, ODEs, partial differential equations, or PDEs]
acceptable: linear differential equations, nonlinear differential equations, ordinary differential equations, ODEs, partial differential equations,

bonuses.leadin: A rebel after this event was known as “the veiled one” due to an explosion created by chemicals that he used to perform magic tricks. For 10 points each:
answers: Abbasid Revolution [accept overthrow of the Umayyad Caliphate or equivalents]
jizya tax
Damascus [or Dimashq; or ash-Shams] <ML, World History>
parts: Name or describe this event during which Khalid al-Qasri led a revolt in Kufa. Abu Muslim led the winning side’s military in this event.

The Umayyad decision to reduce the number of people eligible for this tax and shift the tax burden to Muslims helped spark the Abbasid Revolution. Over time, mass conversion to Islam reduced revenue from this tax.
The revolution broke out in part due to the Umayyad caliphate’s decision to move the capital from this city in present-day Syria, which is now the country’s capital.
answers_formatted: Abbasid Revolution [accept overthrow of the Umayyad Caliphate accept equivalents]

bonuses.leadin: This sort of artwork is exemplified by Marina Abramović’s The Artist is Present, in which participants could sit at a desk across from Abramović, who remained utterly silent. For 10 points each:
answers: performance art
happenings
China [or People’s Republic of China; or PRC; or Zhōnghuá Rénmín Gònghéguó] (The artists are Zhang Huan and Ai Weiwei.) <RR, Other Arts: Misc>
parts: What term loosely describes any artwork involving a live presentation by the artist, often involving an audience?

Allan Kaprow coined this term for early performance art pieces. In one of these performances by Jim Dine, The Smiling Workman, he paints the words “I love what I’m doing HELP” and drinks tomato juice from a paint can.

An artist from this country covered himself in honey and walked into a public bathroom, after which he became covered in flies, in his performance 12 Square Meters. Another artist from this country made a performance art piece by dropping an ancient urn, but is better known for flooding the Tate Modern with sunflower seeds.
answers_formatted: China [or People’s Republic of China; or PRC; or Zhōnghuá Rénmín Gònghéguó]
metadata: The artists are Zhang Huan and Ai Weiwei.

bonuses.leadin: After his death, a gay member of this profession named Parsifal is investigated by his assistant and lover Sabine in a 1997 novel by Ann Patchett. For 10 points each:
answers: magician [or The Magician’s Assistant; or The Magicians; do not accept or prompt on “wizard”]
Clarke [accept Susanna Clarke or Arthur C. Clarke]
Christopher Priest <RK, Misc Lit>
parts: Name this profession that Quentin Coldwater takes up in a trilogy by Lev Grossman. Two Englishman become “practical” members of this profession during the Napoleonic Wars in the novel Jonathan Strange & Mr. Norrell.
Jonathan Strange & Mr. Norrell was written by an author with this surname and first name Susanna. Another author with this surname wrote the screenplay to Stanley Kubrick’s 2001: A Space Odyssey.

This author depicted a feud between the stage magicians Robert Angier and Alfred Borden in his novel The Prestige. A city moves through a desolate land on train tracks in his novel The Inverted World.
answers_formatted: magician [or The Magician’s Assistant; or The Magicians; do not accept or prompt on "“wizard”"]

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about opening lines of classical epics, for 10 points each.
answers: muses [or mousai]
Apollo [or Phoebus Apollo] (The author is Apollonius of Rhodes.)
arms and the man [or arma virumque; accept weapons in place of “arms”] <WA, Myths/Legends>
parts: Homer’s Odyssey begins by asking one of these nine goddesses to “tell me” of the “man of many devices,” referring to Odysseus. These goddesses include Clio.

An invocation to this Greek deity begins the Argonautica by a man from Rhodes who, coincidentally, is also named after this deity. The English word “paean” (“PEE-in”) originally referred to a hymn to this deity.
The opening of Virgil’s Aeneid states that the speaker sings of these two specific things, and of how they brought about “the Latin race, the lords of Alba, and the lofty walls of Rome.”
answers_formatted: arms and the man [or arma virumque; accept weapons in place of “arms”]
metadata: The author is Apollonius of Rhodes.

bonuses.leadin: One of this artist’s paintings depicts the 127-kilogram woman Sue Tilley lying naked on a couch. For 10 points each:
answers: Lucien Freud (The first painting is titled Benefits Supervisor Sleeping.)
Francis Bacon
Battleship Potemkin <AR, Painting/Sculpture>
parts: Name this artist who sits on a wooden chair against an orange background in a triptych by a different artist containing “three studies” of him.
This artist painted Freud, who was both his friend and rival, in Three Studies of Lucien Freud. This Irish artist also created Three Studies for the Base of a Crucifixion and several screaming popes.
Many of Bacon’s works were influenced by this film, such as a shot that depicts a nurse whose broken glasses pierce her bleeding eye. A scene from this film is set on the Odessa Steps.
metadata: The first painting is titled Benefits Supervisor Sleeping.

bonuses.leadin: Recent genomic analyses have suggested that this fish is still evolving, leading some to criticize its common description as a “living fossil.” For 10 points each:
answers: coelacanth (“SEE-luh-kinth”)
Indonesia [or Republic of Indonesia or Republik Indonesia]
Comoros [or Union of the Comoros or Union des Comores or Juzur al-Qumur or Umoja wa Komori] <WA, Geography>
parts: Name this fish that lives in underwater caves and is considered an example of a “Lazarus taxon,” as it was discovered in the wild 66 million years after it was thought to have become extinct.
The two known species of coelacanth live in the western Indian Ocean and this Asian island country. The latter was found near this majority Muslim country’s island of Sulawesi (“soo-luh-WEZ-ee”).

Most West Indian Ocean coelacanths are found near this country, including in its Moheli Marine Park, which is also home to many humpback whales. This country’s name derives from the Arabic word for “moon.”
answers_formatted: Comoros [or Union of the Comoros or Union des Comores or Juzur al-Qumur or Umoja wa Komori]

bonuses.leadin: Silicon is an example of these materials, whose properties are often altered via doping. For 10 points each:
answers: semiconductors [do not accept or prompt on “conductors”]
quantum dots [prompt on dots or artificial atoms]
electron holes [do not accept or prompt on “holons”] <WA, Physics>
parts: Name these materials that have intermediate properties between those of insulators, in which electrons do not flow freely, and materials in which electrons flow more freely, such as copper.

These particles are 2 to 10 nanometers in diameter and have a core composed of semiconducting materials. Because these particles have high surface-to-volume ratios, they can emit fluorescence of highly specific wavelengths.

Quantum dots are confined to areas smaller than the exciton Bohr radius, which is the distance between conduction band electrons and these positively-charged quasiparticles, which represent “missing” electrons.
answers_formatted: electron holes [do not accept or prompt on "“holons”"]

bonuses.leadin: Sun Wukong meets this place’s Ten Yama Kings while traveling to its capital of Youdu (“yoh-doo”). For 10 points each:
answers: Chinese underworld [or Chinese afterlife or Chinese hell or Diyu; prompt on south]
Journey to the West [or Xī Yóu Jì; prompt on Monkey]
Mo Yan [or Guan Moye] (The latter novel is Red Sorghum.) <WA, Long Fiction>
parts: Name this place that is governed by Yama in many other Chinese tales influenced by Indian traditions.
Sun Wukong journeys to the underworld in this classic Chinese novel, in which he accompanies Xuanzang (“shwen-dzong”) on the title trip to India.

Nao is reincarnated as various farm animals after being sent to the underworld in this contemporary author’s novel Life and Death are Wearing Me Out. Douguan (“doh-gwen”) fights the Japanese occupation of Shandong in another of this author’s novels.
answers_formatted: Chinese underworld [or Chinese afterlife or Chinese hell or Diyu; prompt on south]
Journey to the West [or Xī Yóu Jì; prompt on Monkey]
metadata: The latter novel is Red Sorghum.

bonuses.leadin: Pietro Aretino wrote about falling in love with a female member of this profession and thus switching his love interest from boys to girls in My Dear Boy. For 10 points each:
answers: cook [or chef; or equivalents]
Baldassare Castiglione
Venice [or Venezia] <ML, European History>
parts: Name this profession. Books about this profession were produced by Kenelm (“KEN-elm”) Digby and Guillaume (“ghee-YOME”) Tirel.
Aretino’s book La Cortigiana (“cor-tee-JAH-nah”), which is about Messer Maco’s attempt to become a cardinal and find a mistress, is a parody of this Italian diplomat’s Book of the Courtier.

Aretino eked out a comfortable living as a blackmailer in this city, where he was hired by the kings of France and Spain to dig up dirt on each other. This city’s earlier doges (“DOE-jus”) included Enrico Dandolo.

bonuses.leadin: The LOD score is used to determine the probability that two genes have this property. For 10 points each:
answers: linkage [or linked genes]
Gregor Mendel
centimorgan [or cM] <EM, Biology: Genetics/Cell>
parts: Name this phenomenon that violates the law of independent assortment. In this phenomenon, two genes are inherited together due to being close together on the same chromosome.
The law of independent assortment was posited by this Austrian monk based on his work on pea plants.
This unit of genetic linkage is also known as the map unit. One value of this unit separates two genes that segregate 1 percent of the time.

bonuses.leadin: This martial art is often called the “art of eight limbs” in reference to how it employs the hands, legs, elbows, and most notably the knees. For 10 points each:
answers: Muay Thai [prompt on Thai boxing]
Burma [or Myanmar]
Tony Jaa [or Jaa Phanom or Tatchakorn Yeerum] <WA, Other Academic>
parts: Name this form of boxing, partly named for its home country, which is part of a class of martial arts called boran. Yodtong Senanan trained many fighters in this art in Pattaya.

The Muay Thai fighter Nai Khanom Tom (“nye kuh-nome tom”) legendarily won freedom for all Thais (“ties”) taken captive by one of this country’s Konbaung (“kohn-baong”)-dynasty kings by defeating ten champions. This Southeast Asian country’s main river is the Irrawaddy.
This Thai martial artist and Buddhist monk has helped popularize Muay Thai through his appearances in the films Ong-Bak, Tom-Yum Goong, and Fast and Furious 7.

bonuses.leadin: An eight-line poem that analogizes truth to “Lightning… eased / With explanation kind” commands to “Tell all the truth” in this manner. For 10 points each:
answers: slant [accept “Tell all the truth but tell it slant” or “There’s a certain Slant of light”]
Death [or “Because I could not stop for Death”]
rhyme [accept slant rhyme] <RK, Poetry>
parts: Give this word. Another poem uses this word as a noun to refer to a light that gives a “Heavenly Hurt” and forces the landscape to listen and the shadows to hold their breath.

The poem “There’s a certain Slant of light” ends by reflecting on how, “When it goes, ’tis like the Distance / On the look of” this figure. In another poem, this figure “knew no haste” as “the Horses’ Heads / Were toward Eternity.”

Emily Dickinson, the author of those poems, was fond of the “slant” form of this device, as seen in her lines “The Beggar and his Queen / Propitiate this Democrat / A Summer’s Afternoon” with “Queen” and “Afternoon.”
answers_formatted: slant [accept “Tell all the truth but tell it slant” or “There’s a certain Slant of light”]
Death [or “Because I could not stop for Death”]
acceptable: “Tell all the truth but tell it slant”
“Because I could not stop for Death”

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about slaves escaping not north into Canada, but south into Mexico, for 10 points each.
answers: Vicente Guerrero
Sam Houston
Seminoles <JM, US History>
parts: Escape routes into Mexico largely began after this part-black second president of Mexico abolished slavery in 1829. This man himself was overthrown by Anastasio Bustamante, who demanded that Texas comply with the emancipation order.
One of this politician’s slaves, Tom, escaped across the Rio Grande and later joined the Mexican military, which this man had led a war against as the first president of Texas.

In 1852, a group of refugees from slavery who made up part of this Native American tribe successfully petitioned the Mexican government for land. This tribe’s African-American leaders included John Horse.

bonuses.leadin: Orlando Consort performed a groundbreaking 1999 recording of fourteen of these pieces by the 14th-century composer Guillaume de Machaut (“ghee-YOME duh mah-SHOW”), including “Tant doucement” (“tawn doose-MAWN”). For 10 points each:
answers: chansons [or cansos; or cançons or cançó; prompt on songs]
troubadours [or trouvères; or trobadors]
Maurice Ravel (The suite is Le tombeau de Couperin.) <WA, Classical/Opera>
parts: Give the original-language term for these musical pieces, whose three standard formes fixes (“form feeks”), or fixed forms, were the ballade (“buh-LAHD”), rondeau, and virelai (“veer-LAY”).
These wandering Occitan (“OCK-sit-in”) poets, who created many songs of love, also performed grand chansons (“grawn shawn-SAWN”) for the courts of many medieval French nobles.

This 20th-century neoclassical composer’s only a capella piece, Trois Chansons (“twah shawn-SAWN”), was written in response to the outbreak of World War I. He commemorated six friends who died in the same war in a suite styled after the Baroque tombeau genre.
metadata: The suite is Le tombeau de Couperin.

bonuses.leadin: The company RedHat produces a platform called OpenShift that manages these systems and is part of an “open initiative” that seeks to standardize their use. For 10 points each:
answers: containers [accept containerization or Open Container Initiative; prompt on virtual environments; prompt on, but DO NOT REVEAL, OS-level virtualization; do not accept or prompt on “virtual machines”]
virtual machine [or VM; accept Java Virtual Machine or JVM]
operating system [or OS] <RK, Computer Science>
parts: Name these impermanent, isolated execution environments used by software developers to easily package and deploy applications. They have gained traction thanks to companies like Docker and Kubernetes (“koo-ber-NET-iss”).

Containers have become a popular, lightweight alternative to these systems that emulate a physical computer. Java’s slogan “write once, run anywhere” references the fact that Java code is run within one of these systems.

Because multiple containers can share a single kernel, they are examples of virtualization at this level of software between the hardware and application layers. Linux and Windows are examples of this software.
answers_formatted: containers [accept containerization or Open Container Initiative; prompt on virtual environments; prompt on prompt on, but DO NOT REVEAL, OS-level virtualization; do not accept or prompt on "“virtual machines”"]
promptable: prompt on, but DO NOT REVEAL, OS-level virtualization

bonuses.leadin: This saint’s actions include taming a fierce wolf that had been eating the villagers of Gubbio. For 10 points each:
answers: Saint Francis of Assisi [or Francesco; or Giovanni di Pietro di Bernardone]
Poor Clares [or Order of Saint Clare; or Order of Poor Ladies; or Clarisses or Minoresses or Franciscan Clarist Order]
mendicant orders [or ordo mendicans] (The Latin verb is mendicare.) <WA, Religion>
parts: Name this 13th-century saint from Assisi who largely withdrew from public life after his namesake religious order was authorized by Pope Innocent III.
This order of nuns, a companion organization to the Franciscans, was also founded by a namesake saint from Assisi who was one of the first followers of Francis.

Historically, the Franciscans and Poor Clares were examples of religious orders described by this term, meaning that their members relied entirely on charity for their livelihood. This term comes from the Latin word for “to beg.”
answers_formatted: Saint Francis of Assisi [or Francesco; or Giovanni di Pietro di Bernardone]
Poor Clares [or Order of Saint Clare; or Order of Poor Ladies; or Clarisses or Minoresses or Franciscan Clarist Order]

bonuses.leadin: William Nordhaus’s DICE model was created to assess the costs and benefits of proposed policies to deal with this phenomenon. For 10 points each:
answers: climate change [or global warming; prompt on climate]
cap-and-trade [prompt on emissions trading; do not accept or prompt on “carbon tax”]
discount rate [prompt on interest rate or annual interest rate; prompt on discount factor] <WA, Social Science: Econ>
parts: Give this phenomenon, the subject of the Kyoto Protocol. In 2018, Nordhaus argued against a “special report” on this phenomenon, claiming that the report’s proposals would make the world poorer than “doing nothing.”
This policy for reducing the social cost of climate change imposes a ceiling on the amount of carbon emissions and allows people to purchase and sell credits that give them permission to emit.

The social cost of a ton of carbon controversially varies from 1 dollar to over 500 dollars based on how this variable is calculated. The net present value of a cash payment is inversely proportional to [read slowly] “one plus this quantity, all raised to t,” where t is how many years in the future you get paid.
answers_formatted: cap-and-trade [prompt on emissions trading; do not accept or prompt on "“carbon tax”"]
discount rate [prompt on interest rate or annual interest rate; prompt on discount factor]

bonuses.leadin: Joseph de Guignes (“zhoh-ZEFF duh GEEN-yuh”) was one of the first to link these two peoples linguistically, although this has not been proven by archaeological evidence. For 10 points each:
answers: Xiongnu (“sh’yung-noo”) AND Huns [accept Hsiung-Nu or Hiong-Nu in place of “Xiongnu”]
Wei [accept Northern Wei]
khan [or khagan; accept khanate or khaganate] <WA, Ancient/Archaeology>
parts: Name these two oft-conflated ancient peoples. One of them was led by a leader called a chanyu, while the other’s last-known ruler was named Ernak and lost the Battle of the Nedao.

Neither the Xiongnu nor the Huns were a threat in China during the life of the legendary Mulan, who fought for a “Northern” dynasty of this name. Another dynasty of this name was led by the warlord Cao Cao (“tsow tsow”).

The Ballad of Mulan instead depicts her fighting the Rouran (“roh-rahn”), who are the first historical people of note to use this title for their rulers. This Turkic title was also given to the leader of the Mongols.

bonuses.leadin: The protagonist of this story describes himself as a dreamer, which he defines as “not a human being, but a creature of an intermediate sort.” For 10 points each:
answers: “White Nights” [or “Belye nochi”]
Notes From Underground [or Notes from the Underground; or Letters from the Underworld; or Zapíski iz podpól’ya]
Fyodor Dostoevsky [or Fyodor Mikhailovich Dostoevsky] <ML, Short Fiction>
parts: Name this Russian story narrated by a lonely man who wanders the streets of St. Petersburg and develops an affection for Nastenka before she reunites with her lover.

“White Nights” is often compared to this novella, whose reclusive unnamed narrator rails against Western philosophy to the prostitute Liza and introduces himself by stating “I am a sick man…. I am a spiteful man.”
“White Nights” and Notes From Underground were written by this author, who is best remembered for writing about Raskolnikov’s murder of a pawnbroker in Crime and Punishment.
answers_formatted: Notes From Underground [or Notes from the Underground; or Letters from the Underworld; or Zapíski iz podpól’ya]
